text: hi everyone Anthony Fantana here the
Internet's busiest music nerd and this
is the latest full-length LP from New
York Bay singer-songwriter Sharon man
and are we there this is Sharon's latest
full-length album yusin's breaking out
in 2009 with her album epic on bada-bing
records and even though Sharon has
brought on a lot of instrumentation and
guest musicians and producers since her
early days of lo-fi just her and her
zeal just self recorded tapes there's
been a lot of change but Sharon's
foundational songwriting style has been
pretty unwavering slow dramatic indie
rock and folk tunes where Sharon's voice
really just steals the show takes the
reigns in modern singer-songwriter dumb
Sharon is one of my favorite voices and
for whatever reason on this LP much more
than on her previous - she's reminding
me a lot more of Joni Mitchell in a good
way unlike some other singer song
writers out there Sharon's music isn't
really catchy or upbeat or hooky I would
actually even say this is her least
catchy album yes it's coming out with
epic are we there really demands
patience and takes its time it is a slow
burner it is the slow burner of slow
burners not only because a lot of the
songs here work at a very slow or mid
pace but it's also because of how
elongated a lot of the instrumentation
on this record is nothing really
punctuated s' these songs in a really
rhythmic way everything just seems to be
droning on and moving very glacially and
wringing out and I would not call this
record do me or shoegaze or experimental
like that but the the the layered and
very
instrumentation does set a very gloomy
tone to me it's like I'm listening to a
national record I would actually
recommend this album to somebody who was
a fan of the national I think the
instrumentation is a little bit brighter
and personally I find the singing to be
much more engaging
mostly because I find Sharon's voice to
be so powerful so emotive so passionate
now this very slow songwriting style is
something that Sharon has been honing
for years now however I am NOT as drawn
to it as I am her melody writing her
song writing her lyrics and her vocals
the slow instrumentation on this record
I think works in Sharon's favor a lot of
tracks here like Taking Chances
it's also one of the few tracks on this
LP where Sharon takes keyboards and drum
machines and really puts them at the
forefront of the song sounding like
Beach House occasionally and I really
feel like this track and in others on
here is really an attempt at changing up
share and sonic palette a bit but
despite this change this little bit of
window dressing
Sharon's songwriting style pretty much
remains and she delivers one of the most
emotionally crushing choruses on this
entire LP I not only love just how heavy
the drums are at this point in the song
how wonderful Sharon's singing is at
this point in the song but I love the
rhythm and guitar on this track to just
really crunchy cutting through all the
instrumentation just skipping on the
groove in the song your love is killing
me moves that this really glacial three
four time signature at least that's how
I read it and it's like galloping in
slow motion as Sharon calls out in her
lyrics all these ways that she could be
prevented from chasing after this person
whose love is essentially killing her
just have her legs broken so that she
can run after this person extreme but
Sharon delivers these lyrics beautifully
and with a lot of heart and again that
very powerful voice the closing track on
here let's loose a little bit lyrically
Sharon talking about how people are
accusing her of being a one-hit wonder
she's doing dishes she's in
someone's bathroom it's got one of the
sweeter choruses on the LP it's just
really warm it's really rootsy it really
does paint that picture of the Sun
coming up but then Sharon
about being in trouble on this chorus as
well can't let things get too warm after
remind people that they're kind of Jerry
too I suppose
there's a good handful of tracks on this
LP that I really love for their slow
pace for their moody attitude but all
too often I think the instrumentation on
this record because of its a very slow
pace and because of how the guitar is
the keys etc drones on rather than
hitting a really strong rhythm the
record sounds kind of syrupy formless
kind of undefined there are at least a
few tracks on here where I think the
instrumentation turns into this
flavorless mass that masks the song more
than it does enhance it songs like you
know me well and break me tracks to have
great vocal melodies and good choruses
but man does the instrumentation just
get mundane and the verses are just
completely unmemorable to me and I feel
the same way about the opening track on
here to a degree as well tracks like
nothing will change become a welcome
change of pace instrumentally not just
because there are some really nice
woodwinds on this track but because the
instrumentation overall isn't so heavy
it's not so overbearing it's not droning
me into semi boredom and as a result
just the overall tone of the song and
Sharons vocals too are really soft
they're gentle they're intimate they
seduce me musically the track tarrif on
here is great for a lot of the same
reasons but features horns rather than
woodwinds however not every
stripped-back moment on this record is a
total winner for one there are two piano
ballads on here which completely stunned
me in that they aren't two of the more
gripping songs on the record considering
that Sharon really built a name for
herself on just her vocals and her
guitar overall I liked this record but
once again I didn't love it I'm still
sticking with Sharon I'm still looking
forward to what she's doing in the
future considering that still even on
this LP she delivers at least a handful
of songs that I think are fantastic that
I love easily taking chances is one of
her best songs and one of the better
songs of this year but still I think she
allows her instrumentation to either get
the best of her by covering her up
or just not being that interesting of
foundation of course there are tracks on
here where the instrumentation feels
well arranged but there are so many
spots here where it feels really too
bland to be all that gripping I'm
feeling a strong six on this record
transition if you've given this LP
listen what did you think of it did you
love it did you hate it why what do you
think I should review next and that's it
Anthony Fantan Oh Sharon Van Etten
forever
